skill.name: Engineering Fundamentals
skill.description: Auto-invoke for general code quality review. Enforces naming conventions, function size, DRY principles, SOLID principles, and code organization.

skill.author: DanielPodolsky

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing markdown guidelines for code quality review. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, and no command execution capabilities. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: This skill enforces code quality through comprehensive checklists for naming conventions, function design, DRY principles, and SOLID. It helps developers write readable, maintainable code by providing clear guidelines and anti-patterns to avoid.
actual_capabilities: Review variable and function naming conventions
Check function size and single responsibility principle
Verify DRY compliance and code duplication
Apply SOLID principles to code review
Identify anti-patterns like magic numbers and deep nesting
Evaluate code organization and separation of concerns
limitations: Does not execute or test code automatically
Does not modify or refactor code directly
Does not integrate with version control systems

use_cases.title: Code review automation
use_cases.description: Use during code reviews to systematically check naming, function design, and SOLID compliance.

use_cases.title: Team coding standards
use_cases.description: Establish consistent coding standards across the team using provided checklists.

use_cases.title: Learning best practices
use_cases.description: Learn clean code principles through guided checklists and concrete anti-pattern examples.

prompt_templates.title: Basic code review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this function for naming, size, and single responsibility: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: SOLID compliance
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if this class follows SOLID principles. Identify any violations.

prompt_templates.title: Naming audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Review these variable and function names. Suggest improvements for clarity.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture review
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate this code for DRY violations, cohesion, and separation of concerns.

output_examples.input: Review this code: const d = new Date(); const temp = getUser(); function processOrder(order) { /* 150 lines */ }
output: Naming issues found: 'd' and 'temp' are unclear. Use 'createdAt' and 'currentUser' instead.
Function 'processOrder' is 150 lines. Consider breaking into: validateOrder, calculateTotal, saveOrder, sendConfirmationEmail.
Missing early returns increase nesting depth. Use guard clauses for better readability.

best_practices: Use descriptive, full words in names instead of abbreviations or generic terms like 'data' or 'temp'.
Keep functions under 30 lines with single responsibility. Break complex functions into smaller focused functions.
Apply the Rule of Three before abstracting duplication. Premature abstraction creates unnecessary complexity.
anti_patterns: Magic numbers and strings scattered through code instead of named constants.
Deep nested conditionals (more than 3 levels) instead of early returns and guard clauses.
God functions that do everything (validate, calculate, save, email, log) instead of composed single-responsibility functions.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidelines for manual code review. It does not execute in CI/CD environments.

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill is language-agnostic. The principles apply to any programming language.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically fix code issues?
faq.answer: No. This skill identifies issues and provides recommendations. Manual changes are required.

faq.question: Does this skill access my codebase or send data externally?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill. It only processes code you explicitly share in the conversation.

faq.question: How is this different from linters and formatters?
faq.answer: Linters enforce syntax rules. This skill evaluates design, naming, and architecture decisions that require human judgment.

faq.question: Does this skill replace peer code review?
faq.answer: No. It supplements human review with systematic checklists. Peer review remains essential for context and domain knowledge.
